title: 105_s804
content: The Act may be cited as the "War Crimes Prosecution Facilitation Act of 1997". The Congress established the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia in 1993 to prosecute war crimes in the region from 1991 onwards. Parties to the Dayton Agreement agreed to cooperate with the investigation and prosecution of war crimes. All members of the international community are required to assist in identifying and locating individuals involved in these crimes. The International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia was established in 1993 to prosecute war crimes in the region. There are 74 persons under indictment, with 66 still at large, including Bosnian and Yugoslav Serbs, and Bosnian and Croatian Croats. Indicted war criminals have been sighted living openly in areas under the control of Croatia or Serbia-Montenegro. Approximately 2,000,000 people have been displaced by the war. The fighting in Bosnia has stopped, and efforts are now focused on economic reconstruction and implementing the Dayton Accords. International organizations and donor countries, including the United States, are providing funds for the $5.1 billion reconstruction goal. Many people remain displaced and unable to return home due to different ethnic control jurisdictions. The Senate expresses its viewpoint. The Senate emphasizes the importance of reconciliation in Bosnia and Herzegovina, stating that indicted war criminals must be brought to justice, refugees and displaced persons should be able to return home, and assistance should only be provided if it promotes reconciliation and reconstruction. The Senate emphasizes reconciliation in Bosnia and Herzegovina, stating that indicted war criminals must face justice, refugees should be able to return home, and the Tribunal should continue investigating violations of international humanitarian law. SEC. 4. RESTRICTIONS ON FUNDING. No assistance may be provided under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 or the Arms Export Control Act for any country described in subsection (d). The prohibition on assistance includes the provision of assistance from funds appropriated prior to the date of enactment of this Act. The Secretary of the Treasury shall instruct the United States executive directors of international financial institutions to oppose and vote against any extension of financial or technical assistance to countries described in subsection (d), with exceptions. Assistance restrictions do not apply to humanitarian, democratization, or infrastructure projects in sanctioned countries and neighboring non-sanctioned countries. No assistance can be provided in countries with indicted war criminals having financial interests. No assistance can be provided under certain acts to areas in countries where local authorities are not complying with war crimes provisions of the Dayton Agreement. Sanctioned countries are those not complying with specific provisions of the agreement. Sanctioned Countries: Countries failing to apprehend and transfer indicted persons to the Tribunal may face sanctions. The President can waive sanctions if a majority of indicted persons are arrested and transferred within six months. Waivers are effective for six months. The sanctions imposed on a country will only be lifted if the President certifies to Congress that the country has apprehended and transferred all indicted persons to the Tribunal. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "country" excludes Bosnia and Herzegovina, with separate application to Republika Srpska and the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The "Dayton Agreement" refers to the peace agreement signed in 1995. "Democratization assistance" includes support for democratic institutions, while "humanitarian assistance" covers disaster relief, food aid, and support for refugees, education, and health. The curr_chunk discusses assistance for demining, refugees, housing, education, health care, and social services, with a definition of the term "Tribunal" as the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia.
